misconceptions.name: Solves a different physics problem instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The code computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers, checking for even values, and summing them.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should read v0, v1, and t and compute average acceleration (n/t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, select only the even numbers (n % 2 == 0), accumulate their sum, and print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Variables and calculations correspond to average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t
No loop, modulo check, or accumulator for even-number sum appears anywhere in the code
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between two different exercises (physics average acceleration vs. summing even integers), leading to implementing the wrong algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite main so that it reads 5 integers in a loop, checks if each is even using n % 2 == 0, adds even values to a running sum, and prints the final sum.
related_concepts: Loop design for processing multiple inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt text, variable names, and formula n/t) matches a standard average-acceleration exercise and does not mention or handle five integers or even numbers at all.

evidence.note: All variables and text relate to v0, v1, t and average acceleration rather than reading 5 integers and summing even numbers; there is no loop or even-number logic.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers as required
misconceptions.description: The program reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers as specified by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program only needs to read three numeric inputs corresponding to v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly five integer values from standard input, regardless of their names, in order to compute the sum of the even ones.
symptoms: Only three calls to nextDouble()
No code to read five separate integers
Input prompt refers to three values instead of five integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely due to copying or recalling a different exercise with three inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the three nextDouble() calls with code that reads five integers (e.g., using nextInt()) inside a loop or as five separate reads, matching the problem statement.
related_concepts: Matching input type (int vs double) to problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and exactly three nextDouble() calls clearly contradict the requirement to read five integers.

evidence.note: Shows the program only reading three doubles and explicitly prompting for three values, not five integers.

misconceptions.name: Treats println as an expression that produces a numeric value
misconceptions.description: The student attempts to use System.out.println(n) inside an arithmetic expression with x +=, as if println returned a numerical result that could be added to a variable.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that System.out.println(n) evaluates to a numeric value (perhaps n itself or some status) that can be added to a double variable.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, System.out.println(...) has return type void and cannot be used in expressions; it only performs a side effect (printing). Arithmetic expressions must involve values, not void-returning statements.
symptoms: Use of x+=System.out.println(n);
This line will not compile due to 'void cannot be converted to double'
Misuse of output method as if it produced a value for accumulation
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between methods that compute and return values versus methods that only perform side effects like printing.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Call System.out.println(n); on its own line to print, and separately update x with numeric expressions like x += n; if you intend to accumulate numeric values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The specific pattern x+=System.out.println(n); strongly indicates a misconception about println returning a value, not a simple syntax slip.

evidence.snippet:
double x=0;
x+=System.out.println(n);
evidence.note: Shows the student adding the result of System.out.println(n) to a double, implying they think println yields a numeric value.

misconceptions.name: Implementation of the Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented code to calculate average acceleration rather than the required task of finding the sum of 5 even integers. This suggests a misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or an incorrect submission.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they are solving a problem related to physics (kinematics/acceleration) using variables like v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, using a loop structure, checking for even numbers, and accumulating their sum.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integers.
Calculations are for (v1 - v0) / t.
Output prints 'The average acceleration is ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment or submitting code for a completely different task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure the implementation matches the specified inputs, logic (modulus operator and accumulation), and output.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variable names, input prompt, and mathematical formulas clearly indicate a solution for calculating acceleration, which is unrelated to summing even numbers.

evidence.snippet: System.out.print("Enter v0, v1, and t: ");
evidence.note: The input prompt asks for acceleration-related variables, not 5 integers.
The implementation focuses entirely on reading 3 doubles, calculating differences and quotients, and printing an acceleration message.

misconceptions.name: Attempting Arithmetic with Void Method Return Type
misconceptions.description: The student attempts to add the result of `System.out.println(n)` to a numerical variable `x`. Since `System.out.println` has a `void` return type, this operation is invalid and results in a compilation error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `System.out.println(n)` returns a value (possibly the value printed, `n`), which can be used in arithmetic operations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Methods defined as `void` (like `System.out.println`) perform an action but return nothing. Their output cannot be assigned to variables or used in expressions.
symptoms: The code fails to compile due to 'incompatible types: void cannot be converted to double'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion over the difference between methods that return a value and methods that return void/null.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: If you want to use the value of `n` in calculations, use the variable `n` directly (`x += n;`). The `System.out.println()` method is purely for displaying output and cannot be involved in mathematical expressions.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The line `x+=System.out.println(n);` is a direct and unambiguous demonstration of this semantic error.

evidence.snippet: x+=System.out.println(n);
evidence.note: Attempts to use the void return value of println as an operand in addition/assignment.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - Physics calculation instead of even number sum
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have solved a completely different problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates average acceleration. This suggests either a major misunderstanding of the assignment or copying code from a different problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this program should calculate average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user and sum only the even-valued numbers, then print the result.
symptoms: Code asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration (n/t) instead of filtering and summing
Output message says 'average acceleration' not 'sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student likely submitted code from a different assignment or misread the problem statement entirely
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully: you need to read 5 integers, check each one with modulo operator (n % 2 == 0), and accumulate only the even ones into a sum variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: With 99% confidence this is the wrong problem entirely. The code solves a physics calculation (acceleration) rather than the assigned task (sum of even numbers). The variable names (v0, v1, t), the calculation formula (v1-v0)/t, and the output all confirm this is a different problem.

evidence.snippet: System.out.print("Enter v0, v1, and t: ");
evidence.note: Prompt asks for physics variables (v0, v1, t) not 5 integers as specified in problem
Reads only 3 doubles instead of 5 integers

evidence.snippet:
double n=v1-v0;
double r=n/t;
evidence.note: Calculates acceleration (v1-v0)/t instead of filtering/summing even numbers

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The average acceleration is "+r);
evidence.note: Output is about acceleration, not about sum of even numbers

misconceptions.name: Misuse of System.out.println() in assignment
misconceptions.description: The student attempts to assign the return value of System.out.println() to a double variable. System.out.println() returns void, making this a semantic/syntactic error that would prevent compilation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes System.out.println() returns a value that can be accumulated into a variable.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: System.out.println() is a void method that only prints to console; it returns no value and cannot be assigned to a variable. If you want to accumulate a value, use it separately from the println() call.
symptoms: Code will not compile due to 'x+=System.out.println(n);' statement
Compiler error: incompatible types - void cannot be converted to double
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding of void methods and return values in Java
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the assignment operator: either use 'System.out.println(n);' to just print, or use 'x+=n;' followed by 'System.out.println(x);' to accumulate and then print.
related_concepts: Method side effects vs return values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is a clear semantic error. The code 'x+=System.out.println(n);' is syntactically invalid Java. System.out.println() returns void, and void cannot be assigned to a double variable.

evidence.snippet: x+=System.out.println(n);
evidence.note: Attempts to assign return value of void method System.out.println() to double variable x. This code will not compile.

misconceptions.task: Loop structure to process inputs and Conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.name: Complete absence of required loop and conditional logic
misconceptions.description: The student submission lacks both a loop structure for processing multiple inputs and any conditional logic for checking if numbers are even. The problem requires a loop to read 5 integers and a conditional (n % 2 == 0) to filter even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either did not understand the problem requirements or submitted code intended for a different assignment entirely (physics calculation).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must include: (1) a loop (for or while) that iterates 5 times to read each integer, and (2) a conditional statement (if) checking `n % 2 == 0` to identify even numbers. Even numbers are accumulated in a sum variable.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the code
No if statement checking for even numbers using modulo operator
The code performs physics calculations instead of sum logic
Code calculates average acceleration rather than sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have submitted code from a completely different assignment or did not read/understand the problem specification. The code solves an unrelated physics problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the solution using: a for-loop (for i = 0 to 4), read each integer, and inside the loop use if(num % 2 == 0) to check evenness and accumulate the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code visibly contains no loop construct nor any even/odd checking logic. This is objectively absent from the submission.

evidence.note: Entire main method contains no loop or conditional checking logic. Code solves a physics problem, not the required sum-of-evens problem.
